newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary fin min sees falling CPI, steady rates.
newsitem.headline: Hungary fin min sees falling CPI, steady rates.

text.p: Hungary's inflation is likely to drop steadily in the next two years and a substantial increase in interest rates would not be justified, the Finance Ministry said on Tuesday.
"We expect inflation to drop slowly and gradually... in the next two years," deputy secretary of state Csaba Laszlo told a news conference.
The Central Statistical Office said last week that the consumer price index (CPI) showed an 18.8 percent year-on-year rise in March, the same rate as in February.
The March figure broke a 14-month trend of decline, but was better than expected and the Finance Ministry maintains its forecast of 18 percent average inflation for 1997, Laszlo said.
"A substantial rise in inflation during the year cannot be expected," he added.
Analysts earlier said that the CPI may climb up during the period between June and September due to an unusually low basis of seasonal goods prices in 1996.

Laszlo said government securities yields went through an upward correction in the past three weeks, following the National Bank of Hungary's 0.25 percent increase in its six-month deposit interest rates to 21.00 percent.
"But there is no special reason for a further substantial rise in interest rates," he said. "From the inflation side, it's not justified that yields should begin to go upward."
